[[2009 Formula Renault UK season|2009]] }} '''Harry Tincknell''' (born 29 October 1991 in [[Exeter]], [[Devon]]) is a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[auto racing]] driver. ==Career== ===Karting=== Tincknell made his karting dÃ©but in 2001, finishing in the top five of both the Dunkeswell Club Championship and the South West British Championship series. After competing in Cadets in 2002, Tincknell moved up to TKM karts in 2003, winning the Winter Series at the [[Shenington]] kart circuit in [[Oxfordshire]]. He continued at that level in 2004, winning a round at [[Larkhall]]{{cite web|url=http://www.karting.co.uk/results/DisplayResults.asp?SID=SUPER1&DID=20040523&RID=25|title=Super 1 Series: TKM - Round 3 - Larkhall - 23 May 2004|work=karting.co.uk|publisher=UK Karting|accessdate=2010-02-25|date=2004-05-23}} and finished in 27th place in the championship for Connaught Racing. Tincknell moved into the [[KF3|ICA Junior]] Belgian Championship in 2005, and finished in fifth position in the championship, 65 points behind champion [[Laurens Vanthoor]]. Tincknell stayed at ICA Junior level for the 2006 season, competing in the WSK International Series. He finished fourteenth in the championship, despite earning a third place finish at La Conca, [[Italy]]. Tincknell frequented in various series in 2007, competing in no less than eight different championships or trophy races during the season. His best result was fourth in the South Garda Winter Cup, finishing behind Yannick de Brabander, [[AntÃ³nio FÃ©lix da Costa]] and [[Robin Frijns]]. 2008 was Tincknell's final season in karting, and he finished as runner-up in the Euro Rotax Max Challenge. ===Formula Renault=== Tincknell moved into the [[British Formula Renault Championship|Formula Renault UK Winter Series]] in 2008 and finished seventh with points-scoring finishes in each of the four races with [[CRS Racing|CR Scuderia]]. He also contested two races of the FÃ³rmula JÃºnior Portugal Winter Series, finishing in sixth and eighth places during the two races in [[AutÃ³dromo do Estoril|Estoril]]. In 2009, Tincknell remained with the newly-renamed CRS Racing, to contest a full season of Formula Renault UK.{{cite news|url=http://www.sidmouthherald.co.uk/sidmouthherald/news/story.aspx?brand=SMHOnline&category=news&tBrand=devon24&tCategory=newssmh&itemid=DEED06%20Mar%202009%2015%3A45%3A23%3A647|title=Tipton driving ace has sights on F1 glory|work=[[Sidmouth Herald]]|publisher=[[Archant]]|accessdate=2009-03-20|date=2009-03-06}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} He started well, setting the first pole position of the season at [[Brands Hatch]]{{cite web|url=http://tsl-timing.com/?loc=major&season=2009&series=BTCC&event=races&source=toca2006&eventid=91403&table=91403qu1frn&tabletype=gif|title=2009 Michelin Formula Renault UK Championship: QUALIFYING - ROUND 1 - CLASSIFICATION|work=tsl-timing.com|publisher=Timing Solutions Limited|accessdate=2010-02-25|date=2009-04-04}} before finishing behind [[Oliver Webb]] in the first race. Further podiums came at [[Thruxton Circuit|Thruxton]], [[Oulton Park]] and [[Rockingham Motor Speedway|Rockingham]] as Tincknell finished fifth overall in the championship standings. His consistent finishing also earned him the Graduate Cup title, where first-year drivers battle for honours, with the best fifteen finishes for each drivers counting towards the championship. At the conclusion of the season, Tincknell dominated the Winter Series, finishing each of the four races on the podium and winning two of them. He also contested a round of the [[2009 Formula Renault seasons#2009 Formula Renault 2.0 Northern European Cup season|Formula Renault 2.0 Northern European Cup]] at [[Motorsport Arena Oschersleben|Oschersleben]], finishing both races in seventeenth place. Tincknell will continue in the series in [[2010 Formula Renault UK season|2010]], leading a four-car challenge from CRS Racing.{{cite news | url = http://www.crsracing.com/crs/news.php?action=news§ion=4&newsitem=393 | title = CRS reveals new Formula Renault line-up | work = crsracing.com | publisher = [[CRS Racing]] | date = 2010-01-14 | accessdate = 2010-02-25}} Tincknell was also confirmed as one of ten drivers selected by the UK's motorsport governing body, the [[Motor Sports Association]], to take part in its driver development programme, Team UK. Considered to be the top 10 most promising young racing drivers in the UK, each member of the team will receive in-car performance, fitness and nutrition training as well as advanced sports psychology, care of the Brabham Performance Clinic, created by [[David Brabham]].{{cite news | url = http://www.harrytincknellracing.com/newsDetail.php?news_id=69&from=news | title = Tincknell Among Racing Elite For Team UK | work = Harry Tincknell | publisher = RSM | date = 2010-01-18 | accessdate = 2010-03-01}} ===Formula Three=== Tincknell has signed with [[Fortec Motorsport]] to race in the [[British Formula Three Championship]] in 2011.[http://eformulacarnews.com/news_info.php?n=8300 Tincknell Signs with Fortec Motorsports], ''eFormulaCarNews'', January 12, 2011, Retrieved 2011-02-12 ==Racing record== ===Career summary=== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%; text-align:center" !Season !Series !Team !Races !Wins !Poles !F/Laps !Podiums !Points !Position |- !rowspan=2| 2008 |align=left| [[2008 Formula Renault seasons#Formula Renault 2.0 UK Winter Cup|British Formula Renault 2.0 Winter Series]] |align=left rowspan=2| [[CRS Racing|CR Scuderia]] | 4 | 0 | 0 | 0 | 0 | 56 | 7th |- |align=left| [[2008 Formula Renault seasons#FÃ³rmula JÃºnior FR2.0 Portugal(Portugal Winter Series FR2.0)|Portuguese Formula Renault 2.0 Winter Series]] | 2 | 0 | 0 | 0 | 0 | 8 | 13th |- !rowspan=3| 2009 |align=left| [[2009 Formula Renault UK season|British Formula Renault 2.0]] |align=left rowspan=3| [[CRS Racing]] | 19 | 0 | 1 | 2 | 4 | 323 | 5th |- |align=left| [[2009 Formula Renault seasons#2009 Formula Renault 2.0 Northern European Cup season|Formula Renault 2.0 Northern European Cup]] | 2 | 0 | 0 | 0 | 0 | 8 | 33rd |- |align=left| British Formula Renault 2.0 Winter Series | 4 | 2 | 4 | 1 | 4 | 119 |bgcolor="#FFFFBF"| '''1st''' |- ! 2010 |align=left| [[2010 Formula Renault UK season|British Formula Renault 2.0]] |align=left| [[CRS Racing]] | 20 | 2 | 2 | 1 | 7 | 375 | 5th |- ! 2011 |align=left| [[2011 British Formula Three season|British Formula Three]] |align=left| [[Fortec Motorsport]] | 15 | 1 | 1 | 0 | 4 | 63 | 8th |} * * Season in progress. ==Personal== Tincknell attended St. John's School in Sidmouth, Devon, until the age of 12. He then attended Exeter School, where he achieved 10 GCSEs: six As and four Bs. Away from the race track, Tincknell enjoys playing [[golf]], [[Rugby football|rugby]], and [[chess]], as well as supporting [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]], his local football club. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.harrytincknellracing.com/ Official website] *[http://www.driverdb.com/drivers/8191/career/ Tincknell career statistics from Driver Database] *[http://www.facebook.com/pages/Harry-Tincknell-Racing/280089013493?ref=ts/ Facebook page] *[http://www.twitter.com/HarryTincknell/ Tincknell on Twitter] {{Persondata | NAME = Tincknell, Harry | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 29 October 1991 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Exeter]] ([[England]]) | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tincknell, Harry}} [[Category:1991 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:English racecar drivers]] [[Category:British Formula Renault 2.0 drivers]] [[Category:Portuguese Formula Renault 2.0 drivers]] [[Category:Formula Renault 2.0 NEC drivers]] [[Category:British Formula Three Championship drivers]] {{UK-autoracing-bio-stub}} [[de:Harry Tincknell]]
